member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DepthFirstElementAndLinkWalker
member.summary:
Class to enable depth first traversals of the model starting from a particular element or group of elements. Guarantees that elements and element links are visited in an interleaved fashion. For instance: A | B (link) C | D (link) E
would be visited in the order: A, B, C, D, E, assuming IncludeLinks=true. Note that the DepthFirstElementWalker class only makes the depth-first guarantee for elements, so any traversal containing the elements A, C, E in order would be valid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DepthFirstElementWalker.GetRelatedElements(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary:
Get the list of related elements. This list will be traversed in a depth-first fashion, starting from the beginning, so the order of elements in the returned list is important. Derived classes may override this to specify a different set of related elements, or a different ordering within that set.
The default implementation includes all model elements which aren't filtered out, followed by all links which aren't filtered out.
member.param: ModelElement to query for its related elements

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementWalker.ShouldVisitLinkAgain(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementLink,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary:
When looking at the related elements of the given currentElement, if we find a link that has been enqueued for visiting, this function will tell you if it needs to be visited again. This is if the link has been visited before the currentElement (one of its roleplayers) was visited.
For closure walkers, we guarantee that the link will be visited only after the roleplayers are visited (technically, we guarantee that the InternalElementList will contain the link after the roleplayers). Consider this scenario: We have element A that is a roleplayer for 2 relationships AHasBs and CHasAs. During the closure traversal, A is first approached from B through AHasBs. However, it does not have prop-delete on it, so it is not visited but the AHasBs is visited. Later in the traversal, A is approached from C via CHasAs. This time, A is visited because it has prop-delete. Now we get a case where AHasBs was visited before one of its roleplayers (A) was visited. To fix this, if the walkers find that a link has been visited (or rather, been enqueued for visiting) , it should check if it should be visited again (check if it was already visited before currentElement). If so, it should remove the link from the InternalElementList using the methods MarkForRemovalFromInternalElementList and RemoveMarkedElements, and add it to the queue to be visited again.
member.param: The link that was found to be already enqueued for visiting
The current element whose related elements we are visiting

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementWalker.MarkForRemovalFromInternalElementList(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary: Mark an element for removal from the InternalElementList. We mark first and remove later at the end so that the indices remain valid. When marking elements as visited, we store an index in the hashtable which tells us the order that the element was visited in. If the elements were put into the InternalElementList in that order, we can find the element easily using the index. If not a linear search will be used to find the element.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementWalker.RemoveMarkedElements
member.summary: Removes the elements that are marked for removal. Call this at the end of the traversal so that the indices in alreadyVisited remain valid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.ElementPropertyDescriptor.#ctor(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.ElementTypeDescriptor,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainPropertyInfo,System.Attribute[])
member.summary:
The ElementPropertyDescriptor can operate upon a specific element passed in to the constructor, or it can accept a null element.
If a specific element is provided, GetValue(), SetValue(), and the other methods don't need the component argument passed in and can instead use that specific element.
If a null element is provided, GetValue(), SetValue(), and the other methods will use the component argument passed in.
member.param: Owner of this object
ModelElement whose property will be operated upon. This may be null, in which case GetValue() and SetValue() actually use the argument passed in.
Property (Required)
Array of Attributes for this property descriptor

member.summary: The type of component the framework expects for this property. Notice this returns element.GetType(). That is because the object that is being browsed when this property is shown is an ModelElement. So we are faking the PropertyGrid into thinking this is a property on that type, even though it isn't.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.ElementPropertyDescriptor.IsReadOnly
member.summary: We have to override all the abstract members.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.ElementPropertyDescriptor.IsDescribedElementAbandoned(System.Object)
member.summary: This is a special case safety check - if the model file is changed out side VS and the designer is open with bounded elements then those elements are considered abadonded because during reload their store will be set to null but the data binding will try to perform actions because the actual bounded element is not set null - that is OK because the reload will rebind the elements from the new store anyways. See Bug 665344 for more info.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.ElementPropertyDescriptor.CalculateOperationalElement(System.Object)
member.summary: Provide logic for which element to actually use
member.param: The component parameter supplied to the property descriptor
member.returns: The model element on which to operate.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.ElementPropertyDescriptor.TryGetExtensionElement(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary: Attempts to find the extension element of the type described by this EPD.
member.param: The "component" ModelElement that was passed to the EPD.
member.returns: An extension element, or null if one could not be found.
member.remarks: PropertyDescriptors can be cached and reused (e.g. by data-binding), so the this.ModelElement *instance* may or may not be an extension of the supplied "extended" component. Also, the property descriptor might describe a PEL, in which case the extension might be on the MEL. If we can find an instance-based match, we should use it. Otherwise, use a type-based match. If both the MEL and the PEL have an extension of the required use the one from the MEL.

member.remarks: Hack necessary to make ElementPropertyDescriptor work correctly for presentation elements and DSL extensibility. We can't take a dependency on the Diagrams project, so we just make a copy of the appropriate role Guid.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.RolePlayerPropertyDescriptor.IsDescribedElementAbandoned(System.Object)
member.summary: This is a special case safety check - if the model file is changed out side VS and the designer is open with bounded elements then those elements are considered abadonded because during reload their store will be set to null but the data binding will try to perform actions because the actual bounded element is not set null - that is OK because the reload will rebind the elements from the new store anyways. See Bug 665344 for more info.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.RolePlayerPropertyDescriptor.CanPotentiallyChangeRolePlayer(System.Object)
member.summary: Up front check whether it is possible to change the role player at all from the existing value. The existing role player cannot be changed if: - This is a target role on the source, and that source is RolePlayer locked or there is no existing link, and that source's partition is Add locked - This is a source role on the target and the existing source (if any) is RolePlayer locked

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.TrackingPropertyDescriptor
member.summary: Property descriptor class that uses a second property to manage whether it is in a calculated or stored state.

The ElementPropertyDescriptor can operate upon a specific element passed in to the constructor, or it can accept a null element.
If a specific element is provided, GetValue(), SetValue(), andcool, thaznkl the other methods will ignore the object argument passed in and will instead use that specific element.
If a null element is provided, GetValue(), SetValue(), and the other methods will use the object argument passed in.
member.param: Owner of this object
ModelElement whose property will be operated upon. This may be null, in which case GetValue() and SetValue() actually use the argument passed in.
Property (Required)
(Boolean)Property that handles whether this property is tracking.
Array of Attributes for this property descriptor

member.summary:
The ElementPropertyDescriptor can operate upon a specific element passed in to the constructor, or it can accept a null element.
If a specific element is provided, GetValue(), SetValue(), and the other methods will ignore the object argument passed in and will instead use that specific element.
If a null element is provided, GetValue(), SetValue(), and the other methods will use the object argument passed in.
member.param: ModelElement whose property will be operated upon. This may be null, in which case GetValue() and SetValue() actually use the argument passed in.
Property (Required)
(Boolean)Property that handles whether this property is tracking.
Array of Attributes for this property descriptor

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Design.WinFormsDataBindingHelper.CreateComboCellListWrapper(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Object},System.String)
member.summary: Create a wrapper around a list of objects with Display names for binding to a combo dropdown.
member.remarks: Comboboxes are incapable of binding to a pure list of objects as they need something they can interrogate for the DisplayName property they are bound to. Under certain code paths, they will ask for the properties of the collection and throw if they can't find it. That then breaks the dropdown until the list changes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionEnablement.ILinkedUndoContext
member.summary: An interface that provides access to a linked undo mechanism such as the one in Visual Studio

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionEnablement.ILinkedUndoContext.BeginTransaction(System.String)
member.summary: Begin a new transaction. ILinkedUndoContext.BeginTransaction and ILinkedUndoTransaction.Commit/ILinkedUndoTransaction.Abort are always called in pairs. The implementation should be invariant to nested calls to this pair and still maintain the notion of one top-level transaction. Typically a using statement will be used to manage the life of the transaction.
member.param: A description of the transaction.
member.returns: ILinkedUndoTransaction representing the transaction instance.
member.exception: Thrown if the description argument is null.
Thrown if the description argument is an empty string.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionEnablement.ILinkedUndoTransaction
member.summary: A transaction which supports linked undo such as that implemented by Visual Studio

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionEnablement.ILinkedUndoTransaction.Id
member.summary: Identity of the transaction.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionEnablement.ILinkedUndoTransaction.Commit
member.summary: Commit changes made during the transaction. ILinkedUndoContext.BeginTransaction and ILinkedUndoTransaction.Commit/ILinkedUndoTransaction.Abort are always called in pairs. The implementation should be invariant to nested calls to this pair and still maintain the notion of one top-level transaction. Dispose on the Transaction when Commit has not been called will call Abort.
member.exception: Thrown if the transaction is not open.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionEnablement.ILinkedUndoTransaction.Abort
member.summary: Abort this transaction. Attempt to rollback the changes made in the current transaction, else throw an exception. ILinkedUndoContext.BeginTransaction and ILinkedUndoTransaction.Commit/ILinkedUndoTransaction.Abort are always called in pairs. The implementation should be invariant to nested calls to this pair and still maintain the notion of one top-level transaction. Dispose on the Transaction when Commit has not been called will call Abort.
member.exception: Thrown if the transaction is not open.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerOrderChangedEventManager.Add(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainRoleInfo,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Add an event handler that is notified whenever the order of Elements playing a particular domain role has changed for any source ModelElement changes
member.remarks: For example, add an event handler that is notified whenever the order of child columns is changed for any database table. In this example, the "counterpart domain role" is the child-column role.
member.param: The role played by the elements whose order is changed
The delegate that is to be called

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerOrderChangedEventManager.Add(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainRoleInfo,System.Guid,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Add an event handler that is notified whenever the order of Elements playing a particular role in relationships with a particular source ModelElement changes
member.remarks: For example, add an event handler that is called whenever the order of the columns of the Authors table is changed. In this example, the "counterpart domain role" is the child-column role, while the "source ModelElement" is the Authors table.
member.param: The role played by the elements whose order is changed
The Id of the (parent) ModelElement ordering the (child) counterparts
The handler to add

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerOrderChangedEventManager.Remove(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainRoleInfo,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Remove an event handler that is notified whenever the order of Elements playing a particular role in relationships with any source ModelElement changes
member.remarks: For example, remove an event handler that is notified whenever the order of child columns is changed for any database table. In this example, the "counterpart domain role" is the child-column role.
member.param: The domain role played by the Elements whose order is changed
The handler to remove

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerOrderChangedEventManager.Remove(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainRoleInfo,System.Guid,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Remove an event handler that is notified whenever the order of Elements playing a particular role in relationships with a particular source ModelElement changes
member.remarks: For example, remove an event handler that is called whenever the order of the columns of the Authors table is changed. In this example, the "counterpart domain role" is the child-column role, while the "source ModelElement" is the Authors table.
member.param: The role played by the elements whose order is changed
The Id of the (parent) ModelElement ordering the (child) counterparts
The handler to remove

member.summary: Remove an event handler that is notified whenever the order of Elements playing a particular role in relationships with any source ModelElement changes
member.remarks: For example, remove an event handler that is notified whenever the order of child columns is changed for any database table. In this example, the "counterpart domain role" is the child-column role.
member.param: The domain role played by the Elements whose order is changed
The handler to remove

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerOrderChangedEventManagerImpl.Remove(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainRoleInfo,System.Guid,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Remove an event handler that is notified whenever the order of Elements playing a particular role in relationships with a particular source ModelElement changes
member.remarks: For example, remove an event handler that is called whenever the order of the columns of the Authors table is changed. In this example, the "counterpart domain role" is the child-column role, while the "source ModelElement" is the Authors table.
member.param: The role played by the elements whose order is changed
The Id of the (parent) ModelElement ordering the (child) counterparts
The handler to remove

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerOrderChangedEventManagerImpl.NotifyObservers(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Notify observers that the order of Elements in an ordered relationship has changed
member.remarks: Notifies observers of the reodered domain role, then observers of the particular source ModelElement/reordered domain role combination, then calls the base class implementation to notify observer of the domain relationship, domain model, and store.
member.param: object that initiated the event
The RolePlayerOrderChangedEventArgs to pass to the observers

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SortedRuleNotificationList.notifications
member.summary: When RuleNotifications are enqueued, we create one SortedQueue for each new rule priority value. This bucketing will reduce the number of rule notification instances in each SortedQueue, and speed up sorting upon retrieval. In addition, the SortedQueue will delay the sorting upon data retrieving, so insertion won't be slow either.

member.summary: ExtensionElementSerializer Constructor

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElementSerializer.Reset
member.summary: Reset the serializer
member.remarks: Clear the cached information about any derived classes so that it is recalculated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElementSerializer.ReadElements(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This method deserializes nested XML elements inside the passed-in element.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the current element does have nested XML elements, and the call will position the reader at the open tag of the first child XML element. This method will read as many child XML elements as it can. It returns under three circumstances: 1) When an unknown child XML element is encountered. In this case, this method will position the reader at the open tag of the unknown element. This implies that if the first child XML element is unknown, this method should return immediately and do nothing. 2) When all child XML elemnets are read. In this case, the reader will be positioned at the end tag of the parent element. 3) EOF.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ExtensionElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElementSerializer.ReadChildElements(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This method deserializes all child model elements.
member.remarks: The caller will position the reader at the open tag of the first child XML element to deserialized. This method will read as many child elements as it can. It returns under three circumstances: 1) When an unknown child XML element is encountered. In this case, this method will position the reader at the open tag of the unknown element. This implies that if the first child XML element is unknown, this method should return immediately and do nothing. 2) When all child XML elemnets are read. In this case, the reader will be positioned at the end tag of the parent element. 3) EOF.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
In-memory ExtensionElement instance that will get the deserialized data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElementSerializer.ReadExtensionExtendsElementInstance(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: Reads instance of relationship ExtensionExtendsElement.
member.remarks: The caller will position the reader at the open tag of the first XML element inside the relationship tag, so it can be either the first instance, or a bogus tag. This method will deserialize only the first valid instance and ignore all the rest tags (because the multiplicity allows only one instance). When the method returns, the reader will be positioned at the end tag of the relationship (or EOF if somehow that happens).
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ExtensionElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElementSerializer.TryCreateInstance(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,System.Xml.XmlReader,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition)
member.summary: This method creates a correct instance of ExtensionElement based on the tag currently pointed by the reader. If the reader is positioned at a serialized ExtensionElement, a new ExtensionElement instance will be created in the given partition, otherwise null is returned.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at open XML tag of the next element being read. This method should not move the reader; the reader should remain at the same position when this method returns.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
Partition in which new elements should be created.
member.returns: Created ExtensionElement instance, or null if the reader is not pointing to a serialized ExtensionElement instance.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElementSerializer.GetMonikerQualifier(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary: A domain class can be monikerized in different ways: standard /qualifier/key mechanism, custom moniker, or element ID. If the domain class is serialized using standard /qualifier/key mechanism, this method returns the qualifier of the moniker; if the domain class uses other ways for monikerization, this method returns empty string.

ExtensionElement instance to get moniker qualifier from.
member.returns: Value of this element's moniker qualifier property, if it has one, or the value of the container's moniker qualifier property. Or empty string if this element is not monikerized using standard /qualifier/key mechanism.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionExtendsElementSerializer.Read(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: Public Read() method that deserializes one ExtensionExtendsElement instance from XML.
member.remarks: When this method is called, caller guarantees that the passed-in XML reader is positioned at the open XML tag of the ExtensionExtendsElement element that is about to be deserialized. The method needs to ensure that when it returns, the reader is positioned at the open XML tag of the next sibling element, or the close tag of the parent element (or EOF).
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ExtensionExtendsElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionExtendsElementSerializer.ReadTargetRolePlayer(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This method reads the target role player ModelElement.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at the open tag of the first child XML element. This method will read only one target role player instance. The method will skip any child XML element it encounters until it reaches: 1) The open tag of the target role player. 2) The end tag of the parent element (dangling relationship). 3) EOF (dangling relationship). After the call, the reader is positioned at: 1) The open tag of the next child element after the target role player. 2) The end tag of the parent element. 3) EOF.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ExtensionExtendsElement instance that will link to the target ModelElement instance.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionExtendsElementSerializer.ReadPropertiesFromAttributes(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This method deserializes all properties that are serialized as XML attributes.
member.remarks: Because this method only handles properties serialized as XML attributes, the passed-in reader shouldn't be moved inside this method. The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned on the open XML tag of the current element being deserialized.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ExtensionExtendsElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionExtendsElementSerializer.ReadElements(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This methods deserializes nested XML elements inside the passed-in element.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the current element does have nested XML elements, and the call will position the reader at the open tag of the first child XML element. This method will read as many child XML elements as it can. It returns under three circumstances: 1) When an unknown child XML element is encountered. In this case, this method will position the reader at the open tag of the unknown element. This implies the if the first child XML element is unknown, this method should return immediately and do nothing. 2) When all child XML elemnets are read. In this case, the reader will be positioned at the end tag of the parent element. 3) EOF.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ExtensionExtendsElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionExtendsElementSerializer.TryCreateInstance(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,System.Xml.XmlReader,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition)
member.summary: This method creates a correct instance of ExtensionExtendsElement based on the tag currently pointed by the reader. If the reader is positioned at a serialized ExtensionExtendsElement, a new ExtensionExtendsElement instance will be created in the given partition, otherwise null is returned.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at open XML tag of the next element being read. This method should not move the reader; the reader should remain at the same position when this method returns.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
Partition in which new elements should be created.
member.returns: Created ExtensionExtendsElement instance, or null if the reader is not pointing to a serialized ExtensionExtendsElement instance.

member.summary: This method creates a correct derived instance of ExtensionExtendsElement based on the tag currently pointed by the reader. Note that the difference between this method and the above one is that this method will never create an instance of the ExtensionExtendsElement type itself, only derived types are checked.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at open XML tag of the next element being read. This method should not move the reader; the reader should remain at the same position when this method returns.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
Partition in which new elements should be created.
member.returns: Created instance that derives from ExtensionExtendsElement, or null if the reader is not pointing to such a serialized instance.

Also, the strings are retrieved from a normal resources file, rather than a generated one.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.ReadRootElement(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ISchemaResolver)
member.summary: Public ReadRootElement() method that deserializes a root-level element from XML. The difference between root-level element and the rest elements in the XML is that the root may carry additional information like schema, version, etc. The default implementation just calls Read() method, it's up to the derived implementations to do any additional checks.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ModelElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
An ISchemaResolver that allows the serializer to do schema validation on the root element (and everything inside it).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.WriteRootElement(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlWriter)
member.summary: Public WriteRootElement() method that serializes a root-level element to XML. The difference between root-level element and the rest elements in the XML is that the root may carry additional information like schema, version, etc. The default implementation just calls Write() method with no RootElementSettings, it's up to the derived implementations to do any additional checks.
member.param: Serialization context.
ModelElement instance that will be serialized.
XmlWriter to write serialized data to.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.Read(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: Public Read() method that deserializes the given ModelElement instance from XML.
member.remarks: When this method is called, caller guarantees that the passed-in XML reader is positioned at the open XML tag of the element that is about to be deserialized. The method needs to ensure that when it returns, the reader is positioned at the open XML tag of the next sibling element, or the close tag of the parent element (or EOF).
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ModelElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.Write(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlWriter)
member.summary: Public Write() method that serializes the ModelElement instance associated with this serializer instance into XML. This method just calls Write() with no RootElementSettings.
member.param: Serialization context.
ModelElement instance that will be serialized.
XmlWriter to write serialized data to.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.Write(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlWriter,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RootElementSettings)
member.summary: Public Write() method that serializes the ModelElement instance associated with this serializer instance into XML.
member.param: Serialization context.
ModelElement instance that will be serialized.
XmlWriter to write serialized data to.

The root element settings if the passed in element is serialized as a root element in the XML. The root element contains additional information like schema target namespace, version, etc. This should only be passed for root-level elements. Null should be passed for rest elements (and ideally call the Write() method without this parameter).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.Reset
member.summary: Returns the serializer to its initial state
member.remarks: If the serializer is stateful, then this method resets it to its initial state.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.TryCreateInstance(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,System.Xml.XmlReader,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition)
member.summary: With the given XmlReader, check if it is currently pointing to a serialized ModelElement instance that this serializer can handle. If so, create an instance of the ModelElement in the given Partition; otherwise return NULL. Note: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at open XML tag of the element being read. This method should not move the reader; the reader should remain at the same position when this method returns.
member.remarks: Note: that this method only tries to create the ModelElement instance, without actually deserializing it. The deserialization will be done by the Read() methods. There are two reasons for this separation: 1) We may need to link the created ModelElement to its parent element (through embedding relationship) before we can deserializing it properly. 2) The deserialization can be customized.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read from.
Partition in which the new element will be created.
member.returns: The created ModelElement instance, or null if the reader is not pointing to a correct serialized instance.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.MonikerTagName
member.summary: Returns the XML tag name when serializing the handled ModelElement as a moniker. Note that this tag name is different from XmlTagName. This one is for writing a moniker, while XmlTagName is for writing the actual instance of the ModelElement. They need to be different tag names so that the associated schema for the serialized XML is not ambiguous. An serializer implementation that overrides MonikerAttributeName should also override MonikerTagName. The base implementation returns empty string, meaning that the DomainClass cannot be monikerized.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.MonikerAttributeName
member.summary: Returns the XML attribute name that contains the moniker string. For example, a DomainClass Foo may have MonikerTagName "FooMoniker", and MonikerAttributeName "ref", then a serialized moniker of Foo will look like <FooMoniker ref="foo1" >. An serializer implementation that overrides MonikerTagName should also override MonikerAttributeName. The base implementation returns empty string, meaning that the DomainClass cannot be monikerized.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.TryCreateMonikerInstance(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,System.Xml.XmlReader,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Guid,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition)
member.summary: With the given XmlReader, check if it is currently pointing to a monikerized instance of a ModelElement that this serializer can handle. If so, create an Moniker instance in the given Store; otherwise return NULL. Note: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at open XML tag of the element moniker being read. This method will move the reader (unlike TryCreateInstance() method) because it may needs to read the serialized moniker string. If the reader is moved, it should be positioned at the closing tag of the element (so that the caller can call SerializationUtilities.SkipToNextElement() to move to the next element).
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
The source role-player ModelElement from which the moniker being created is referenced.
The DomainClass Id of the relationship that connects the sourceRolePlayer to the moniker being created.
The new Moniker should be created in the Store associated with this partition.
member.returns: The created moniker, or null if the reader is not pointing to a correct monikerized instance.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.WriteMoniker(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlWriter,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainRelationshipXmlSerializer)
member.summary: Public WriteMoniker() method that writes a monikerized ModelElement instance into XML.
member.param: Serialization context.
Element to be monikerized.
XmlWriter to write serialized data to.
Source element that references the element to be monikerized.
Serializer that handles the relationship connecting the source element to the element being monikerized.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.ReadPropertiesFromAttributes(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This method deserializes all properties that are serialized as XML attributes.
member.remarks: Because this method only handles properties serialized as XML attributes, the passed-in reader shouldn't be moved inside this method. The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned on the open XML tag of the current element being deserialized.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ModelElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassXmlSerializer.ReadElements(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: This methods deserializes nested XML elements inside the passed-in element.
member.remarks: The caller will guarantee that the current element does have nested XML elements, and the call will position the reader at the open tag of the first child XML element. This method will read as many child XML elements as it can. It returns under three circumstances: 1) When an unknown child XML element is encountered. In this case, this method will position the reader at the open tag of the unknown element. This implies the if the first child XML element is unknown, this method should return immediately and do nothing. 2) When all child XML elemnets are read. In this case, the reader will be positioned at the end tag of the parent element. 3) EOF.
member.param: Serialization context.
In-memory ModelElement instance that will get the deserialized data.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.

Note: The caller will guarantee that the reader is positioned at open XML tag of the element being read. This method should not move the reader; the reader should remain at the same position when this method returns.
member.remarks: Note: that this method only tries to create the derived ElementLink instance, without actually deserializing it. The deserialization will be done by the Read() methods. There are two reasons for this separation: 1) We may need to link the created link to its source role player before we can deserializing it properly. 2) The deserialization can be customized.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read from.
Partition in which the new link will be created.
member.returns: The created ElementLink instance, or null if the reader is not pointing to a correct serialized instance.

DomainClassId of the model element that the given moniker string will be resolved to.

Store where the Moniker will be created

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializationBehavior
member.summary: This is the base class for all XmlSerializationBehavior-generated classes.
member.remarks: Each XmlSerializationBehaivor defines a set of behaviors of how to serialize the DomainClasses in the model to XML, which causes a set of serializers (all deriving from DomainXmlSerializer) to be generated. The main purpose of the DomainXmlSerializationBehavior class is to provide a mapping from DomainClass to its serializer at run-time.

member.summary: This provides a mapping from xml namespaces to domain model implementation types.

member.summary: This provides a mapping from property type to DomainPropertyXmlSerializerImplementation type to use for serialization.
member.remarks: This method is virtual and returns an empty collection by default as most DSLs don't have external types that require special serialization.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory
member.summary: This class is meant to be used at runtime to combine all XmlSerializationBehaviors and xml namespaces from different DomainModels together. Typically, a user will choose more than one models (e.g. one for in-memory model and one for presentation elements). Each model will need an associated behavior to get serialized/deserialized properly. Since relationships can connect model elements across domains, it is necessary to have a single lookup that maps all used DomainClasses to their serializers.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory.serializerTypes
member.summary: A dictionary that maps DomainClass Id to DomainClassXmlSerializer types.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory.serializers
member.summary: A dictionary that maps DomainClass Id Guid to DomainClassXmlSerializer instances.
member.remarks: The reason that we keep two dictionaries to map DomainClassInfo to both serializer types and instances is that we don't want to create all serializer instances at once. The mapping to the types tell what serializers will be created, and once they are created on first use, they'll be stored into this second mapping.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory.registeredPropertySerializerTypes
member.summary: A map of registered property types -> DomainPropertyXmlSerializer types.
member.remarks: Stores the custom serializer data provided when loading domain models i.e. which serializer type to for a given property type.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory.propertySerializerInstances
member.summary: A map of serializer types -> DomainPropertyXmlSerializer instances.
member.remarks: Stores instance of serializers that have already been created. Means that we can re-use the same serializer instance for multiple types if necessary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainXmlSerializerDirectory.propertyToSerializerMap
member.summary: Map of property type -> serializer instance
member.remarks: Used to look up the serializer instance to use for a particular property type. A property type will be mapped to a null value if there isn't an appropriate custom serializer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RootElementSettings.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Gets and Sets additional properties. The default generated serialization code doesn't use any additional properties. This is designer for customization code to pass additional information, if necessary. On get, the given setting name is compared by ordinal, and null is returned if the given setting name doesn't match any stored setting value. On set, if there's an existing setting with the same name (compared by ordinal), the new value will replace the old one with no error. The setting name has to be non-empty.
member.param: Name of the setting to lookup.
member.returns: Value of the setting, or null if not found.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext
member.summary: This class defines the context of a serialization operation. The context passed to each participating serializers to provide information that they may use, and the context stores serialization results collected from each participating serializers.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext.TransactionContextKey
member.summary: Unique key used to identify SerializationContext instances in the TransactionContext property bag

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext.directory
member.summary: A serializer instance needs to look up for other serializer instances during serialization/deserialization, so this directory provides the lookup service.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext.location
member.summary: In read operation, this is the source's location; in write operation, this is the destination location. Usually this is a file path, but it can be other format as well, depending on the underlying source/destination. It can be null as well if the location is not available, e.g. serializing to a string buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext.result
member.summary: This is the SerializationResult collected from all serializers participating in the current serialization operation.

member.summary: In read operation, this is the source's location; in write operation, this is the destination location. Usually this is a file path, but it can be other format as well, depending on the underlying source/destination. member.summary: Whether optional properties with default value should be written out during serialization.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext.Item(System.String)
member.summary: Indexer to access properties stored in this context. The property name is compared by case-sensitive ordinal string comparison. If a property already exists in the context, setting it will override the old value with the new value. If a property doesn't exist in the context, getting it will return null, therefore setting a property to null will remove it from the context (i.e. null and non-existing values are not distinguishable).
member.param: Name of the property, must by non-empty string.
member.returns: Value of the proeprty, null if the property doesn't exist in current context.

If the transaction is nested the transaction stack is searched to find the nearest enclosing serialization transaction with a SerializationContext.

member.returns: The SerializationContext active in the nearest enclosing serialization transaction, or null if none

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationUtilities.SkipToFirstChild(System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: Move the reader to the open tag of the first child element. - If the reader is not on a open tag (including empty tag), the method does nothing (no move). - If the reader doesn't have any nested child element, the method will move the reader to the matching close tag.
member.param: The reader to move.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationUtilities.SkipToNextElement(System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: Assign the reader to the start tag of the next element. This is usually used after a ReaderInnerXml() call, where the reader will be positioned after the close tag of the previous element. Since there may be whitespace or comments between the two elements, the reader may not be moved onto the start tag of the next element automatically. If the reader is already on a start tag, this method will do nothing. The method will also stop if an end tag is encountered, which means there's no more siblings and the end of the parent element is reached.
member.param: The reader to skip.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationUtilities.SkipOneToken(System.Xml.XmlReader)
member.summary: Make the given reader to skip the next token.
member.param: Reader to skip.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationUtilities.ReadExtensions(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SerializationContext,System.Xml.XmlReader,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition)
member.summary: Reads extension elements from the supplied reader.
member.remarks:
If the reader is positioned at an extensions XML element, the method will read all of the ExtensionElements inside the extensions element. When the method returns, the reader will be positioned at the end tag of the extensions tag. If the reader is not positioned at an extensions element tag, the method will do nothing.
Note that the top-level extension elements read by this method will not be embedded in any other element.
member.param: Serialization context.
XmlReader to read serialized data from.
Partition in which to create the extension elements.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement.CommonBaseExtensionClass(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassInfo,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassInfo)
member.summary: Return the common base class of two extension classes. This will be ExtensionElement or some derived extension element class.
member.returns: Non-null DomainClassInfo describing the most derived but common base class of extensionClass1 and extensionClass2

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement.HasClashingExtension(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.DomainClassInfo)
member.summary: Determines whether this element has existing extensions (directly or indirecly) that would clash with an extension of the specified type. In this context an extension is considered to clash if it is the same type (which would mean it could not be be located unambiguously by type) or shares a common base class derived from ExtensionElement that has or inherits properties or roles other than those inherited from ExtensionElement or ModelElement. This definition is tight enough to prevent ambiguity of properties or roles contributed to the extended element, but loose enough to allow extension element class hierarchies that define behaviour (and non-IMS state) in a common base class.
member.returns: true if an existing extension would clash with an extension of the specified type, else false

member.remarks: Note that assuming the Extensions collection is maintained through the Extensibility API then there can be only one extension of a particular type present, so only the first found is removed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ExtensionElement.CanMerge(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ProtoElementBase,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupPrototype)
member.summary: Returns a value indicating whether the source element represented by the specified root ProtoElement can be added to this element.
member.param: The root ProtoElement representing a source element. This can be null, in which case the ElementGroupPrototype does not contain an ProtoElements and the code should inspect the ElementGroupPrototype context information.
The ElementGroupPrototype that contains the root ProtoElement.
member.returns: true if the source element represented by the ProtoElement can be added to this target element.
member.remarks: Override because we must ask the extended MEL whether it will accept the merge of ExtensionElements. This is necessary to allow us to refuse merges of MEXs that would create ambiguous roles or properties.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IMergeElements.MergeRelate(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroup)
member.summary: Called by the Merge process to create a relationship between this target element and the specified source element. Typically, a parent-child relationship is established between the target element (the parent) and the source element (the child), but any relationship can be established.
member.param: The element that is to be related to this model element.
The group of source ModelElements that have been rehydrated into the target store.
member.remarks: Override this method to create the relationship between this target element and the specified source element.
The base method does nothing.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IMergeElements.MergeDisconnect(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary: Performs operation opposite to MergeRelate - i.e. disconnects a given element from the current one (removes links created by MergeRelate).
member.param: Element to be unmerged/disconnected.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IMergeElements.MergeConfigure(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroup)
member.summary: Called by the Merge process to allow this model element to configure itself immediately after the Merge process has related it to the target element.
member.param: The group of source ModelElements that have been rehydrated into the target store.
member.remarks: Override this method to configure the element during the Merge process.
The base method does nothing.
The ElementGroupPrototype's Source and Target Context bags are available into the Top-Level Transaction's Context bag when this method is invoked.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Moniker.Location
member.summary: Even though a Moniker is a concept in the model that doesn't tie to a physical location in serialized format, it is usually used in serialization/deserialization. The location of the moniker in the serialized format can greatly help analyze problems with unresolved monikers, so we store the location of where the moniker is stored in serialized format. The location is optional, and can be null if not available (e.g. Moniker created in memory).

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ReadOnlyLinkedElementCollection`1.Microsoft#VisualStudio#Modeling#INotifyObservers#OnCollectionChanged(System.Collections.Specialized.NotifyCollectionChangedEventArgs,System.Int32)
member.summary: Collection change notifier Supports the following events: * INotifyCollectionChanged.CollectionChanged * INotifyPropertyChanged.PropertyChanged * IBindingList.ListChanged
member.param: Notification action
The count at the moment of the notification action
member.remarks: The index values passed in the notification event args are historical i.e. they reflect the state of the collection at the time that change was made. However, since the transaction has now committed, those index values dont necessarily bear any relation to the current state of the collection. As such, the index values in the notification event args should only be used when synchronising an external copy of the collection: they shouldnt be used as index values into the IMS collection.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.RolePlayerLinksCollection.Debug_ValidateLinksDataStructures(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement)
member.summary: Debug-only method. Verifies that the links data structure for this collection is valid. Includes checking the individual links and role players.
member.remarks: Called in debug code after recreating an ElementGroup from an ElementGroupPrototype. Runtime equivalent of the checks in ModeluingUnitTests\Elements\ElementLinkTests.cs "VerifyElementLinks". We need both versions so we can run the unit tests against release builds. The collection doesn't contain a backpointer to the "owning" model element, so this is a static method that takes owning element as a parameter.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SimpleMonikerResolver.LookupTable
member.summary: Lookup table to ncapsulate the process of looking up a moniker to get a mel. Several mels may actually have the same full form reference. E.g. (in xpath terms) /namespace[@name="A"]/class[@name="B"] and /class[@name="A"]/class[@name="B"] could both have moniker references "/A/B". We can disambiguate them by observing that the relationship is different in each case - we have a constraint that within a relationship the same reference cannot be used by two different mels. So for each reference we stroe either a single mel or a colelction of mels. At resolve time we disambiguate between multiple mels by examining which one could play the moniker'd role in the Moniker.Link

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SimpleMonikerResolver.LookupTable.lookupTable
member.summary: Table containing map of full string references to ModelElement, or a List of ModelElements When a model element is created during deserialization, we calculate its key and then enter it into this table. At end of deserialization, we resolve all monikers by looking them up in this table.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator
member.summary: Class responsible for reconstituting an ElementGroup from an ElementGroupPrototype. Elements and links are created into the correct partitions as directed by the store's partition mapping service. Maintains internal state that records the reconstituted elements and allows lookup of those elements (which might be spread across multiple partitions) by the original prototype element's id without needing to search element directories across the store.

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator.prototype
member.summary: The EGP being reconstituted

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator.partition
member.summary: The target partition

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator.idMap
member.summary: Dictionary mapping original element Id's to reconstituted element Id's

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator.reconstitutedObjects
member.summary: Collection of reconstituted elements and links, keyed by new id

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator.reconstitutedRootElementIds
member.summary: List of new ids of the reconstituted root elements

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupHydrator.partitionMapper
member.summary: Service responsible for determining the partitions in which elements and links are reconstituted

The target partition, typically the partition of the target element into which the group will be merged
Partition mapper responsible for identifying the partitions in which to create elements

member.summary: Dictionary mapping original element Id's to reconstituted element Id's

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroup.SkipAddingElement(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a flag indicating whether it is "safe" to add the client
member.remarks: Optimisation : if we have already added the element/link, and the value of includeLinksAutomatically is false then we don't need to keep going. However, if includeLinksAutomatically=true, we must keep going. If we don't, then calling AddGraph(x, true) won't add any elements if x happens to have been added by a prior operation.

This is implemented outside of CanCopy, so that subclasses can override the public CanCopy and CanMove methods independently. If subclasses want to have the same behavior for both CanCopy and CanMove, they can just override this method. (Before this method existed, overriding only CanCopy led to the side effect of changing the CanMove behavior.)

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether MergeElementGroupPrototype can be performed given the particular hoist and element group prototype. The CanMergeElementGroupPrototype process calls this overload for each root ProtoElement in the ElementGroupPrototype to determine if either the target element or the target's associated model element (if applicable) can serve as the target of the element represented by the ProtoElement.
member.param: The ModelElement that will serve as the target for the reconstituted elements from the ElementGroupPrototype.

A root ProtoElement in the ElementGroupPrototype that, when reconstituted, will become merged into the target element. This parameter can be null, in which case the ElementGroupPrototype does not contain any ProtoElements.
The ElementGroupPrototype containing the root ProtoElements.
member.returns: a value indicating whether MergeElementGroupPrototype can be performed given the particular target and child.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementOperations.MergeCore(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Windows.Forms.IDataObject)
member.summary: Core merge code.
member.param: The ModelElement that is the target for the ElementGroupPrototype.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementOperations.MergeElementGroupPrototype(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupPrototype)
member.summary: Merges the source ElementGroupPrototype with the specified target ModelElement. This method performs the following: (1) reconstitutes the elements from the ElementGroupPrototype, (2) calls OnElementsReconstituted to provide any ElementOperations-derived class the opportunity to plug in custom processing, (3) calls the target element's MergeRelate virtual method for each reconstituted root element to provide the target with the opportunity to connect a root element to itself, (4) calls the virtual method MergeConfigure on the reconstituted root element immediately after calling MergeRelate to provide the root element with an opportunity to configure itself, and (5) calls OnMerged to provide any ElementOperations-derived class the opportunity to plug in custom processing.
member.param: The target element which will serve as the parent of the reconstituted elements.
The source ElementGroupPrototype.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementOperations.MergeElementGroup(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroup)
member.summary: Merges the source ElementGroup with the specified target ModelElement. This method is intended for use when an ElementGroupPrototype is not available, that is, when a collection of actual ModelElements should be merged. If an ElementGroupPrototype is available (e.g., clipboard scenarios), call MergeElementGroupProtoype instead. This method performs the following: (1) calls the target element's MergeRelate virtual method for each root element in the group to provide the target with the opportunity to connect a root element to itself, (2) calls the virtual method MergeConfigure on the root element immediately after calling MergeRelate to provide the root element with an opportunity to configure itself, and (3) calls OnMerged to provide any ElementOperations-derived class the opportunity to plug in custom processing.
member.param: The target element which will serve as the parent of the reconstituted elements.
The source ElementGroup.

member.returns: The target element for the merge.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementOperations.CanDelete(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,System.Guid[])
member.summary: Query whether a specified element can be deleted, taking into account any IMS locks applicable to any of the elements in the delete closure of the element. An element cannot be deleted if any element in the closure is Delete locked, or if any element is the target of a link sourced on an element with the RolePlayer lock AND that element is outside the closure.
member.param: Candidate ModelElement for deletion
A list of domain role ID-s through which delete should not be propagated.
member.returns: true if the element can be deleted, false if not

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementOperations.CanDelete(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement},System.Guid[])
member.summary: Query whether a specified set of elements can be deleted, taking into account any IMS locks applicable to any of the elements in the complete delete closure of the elements. The elements cannot be deleted if any element in the closure is Delete locked, or if any element is the target of a link sourced on an element with the RolePlayer lock AND that element is outside the closure.
member.param: Candidate ModelElements for deletion
A list of domain role ID-s through which delete should not be propagated.
member.returns: true if the all the elements can be deleted, false if any cannot OR the collection is empty

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SElementPartitionMapper
member.summary: Service identifier for the element group rehydration partition mapping service

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IElementPartitionMapper
member.summary: Interface for service used to map elements partitions when reconstituting ElementGroupPrototypes
member.remarks: ProtoLinks are always reconstituted into the partition of the source of the relationship, so the partition mapper is not asked to resolve partitions for links.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IElementPartitionMapper.BeginMapping(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupPrototype,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition)
member.summary: Notification that a series of partition mapping requests are bout to be made for a particular ElementGroupPrototype and merge (or target) partition. This is an opportunity to perform one-off initialization and establish a context for the subsequent mapping calls.
member.param: The ElementGroupPrototype that is being, or is to be, reconstituted.
The merge target partition. Not necessarily where the elements will be reconstituted.
member.returns: An object, e.g. a cookie or context specific state, that has meaning to the partition mapper.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IElementPartitionMapper.PartitionForElement(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupPrototype,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ProtoElement,System.Object)
member.summary: Determine the partition to be used to reconstitute a prototype element
member.param: The ElementGroupPrototype containing protoElement
The merge target partition. Not necessarily where the elements will be reconstituted.
The prototype element being (or to be) reconstituted
The object returned by this partition mapper when BeginMapping was called. Can be null if not used.
member.returns: Partition in which to reconstitute the element

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IElementPartitionMapper.EndMapping(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementGroupPrototype,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition,System.Object)
member.summary: Notification that the ElementGroupHydrator argument has finished reconstituting elements and will not be making any more partition resolution requests. An opportunity to tear down any per-hydration state.
member.param: The ElementGroupPrototype that is being, or is to be, reconstituted
The merge target partition. Not necessarily where the elements will be reconstituted.
The object returned by this partition mapper when BeginMapping was called. Can be null if not used.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.IElementPartitionMapper.PartitionForClass(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition,System.Guid)
member.summary: Determine the partition to be used as the default for instantiation of elements of the specified class
member.param: The partition to use where the mapper doesn't have an alternative
The id of the domain class of which an instance is being created
member.returns: Partition in which to create an element of the specified class
member.remarks: In some cases the partition for an element may be ambiguous given only the element type, in which case the returned partition is down to the arbitrary choice of the partition mapper.

member.summary: Create a clone of this prototype's progenitor ElementGroup.
member.remarks: This overload of ReconstituteGroup is more efficient in that it is able to take advantage of the element map built by the rehydrator as it was creating elements. member.param: ElementGroupHydrator that created the clone elements and links from the EGP
member.returns: The clone

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.NullLockingPolicy
member.summary: A null, or "don't care", locking policy that accepts any locks requests through the API as-is. This is the default Store locking policy.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.SLockingPolicy
member.summary: Service identifier for IMS locking policy service.
member.remarks: The service so identified must implement ILockingPolicy. The store requests this service at initialization time only, so once initialized it cannot be changed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.ILockingPolicy
member.summary: Service interface allowing host to refine IMS locks requested through the Immutability API.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.ILockingPolicy.RefineLocks(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Store,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.Locks)
member.summary: Return the actual Locks that should be applied to the specified Store given a set of proposed Locks.
member.param: The Store whose lock flags are being manipulated
The new set of store Locks requested through Store.SetLocks
member.returns: The actual set of locks to apply, which may include additional locks, or be a subset.
member.remarks: This extension point is called when an attempt is made to apply locks to a Store through the Immutability API. It allows the owner of the Store to apply policy in deciding what locks can be applied or removed.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.ILockingPolicy.RefineLocks(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.Locks)
member.summary: Return the actual Locks that should be applied to the specified Partition given a set of proposed Locks.
member.param: The Partition whose lock flags are being manipulated
The new set of partition Locks requested through Partition.SetLocks
member.returns: The actual set of locks to apply, which may include additional locks, or be a subset.
member.remarks: This extension point is called when an attempt is made to apply locks to a Partition through the Immutability API. It allows the owner of the store to apply policy in deciding what locks can be applied or removed. Implementations may want to ignore lock refinements for partitions it does not own.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.ILockingPolicy.RefineLocks(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement,Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.Locks)
member.summary: Return the actual Locks that should be applied to the specified ModelElement given a set of proposed Locks.
member.param: The ModelElement whose lock flags are being manipulated
The new set of element Locks requested through ModelElement.SetLocks
member.returns: The actual set of locks to apply, which may include additional locks, or be a subset.
member.remarks: This extension point is called when an attempt is made to apply locks to a ModelElement through the Immutability API. It allows the owner of the store to apply policy in deciding what locks can be applied or removed. Implementations may want to ignore lock refinements for elements they do not own.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.Locks
member.summary: Types of locks that can be applied to elements, partitions, and the store

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Immutability.ImmutabilityExtensionMethods.CanDeleteElements(Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement},System.Guid[])
member.summary: Query whether a specified set of elements can be deleted, taking into account any IMS locks applicable to any of the elements in the complete delete closure of the elements. The elements cannot be deleted if any element in the closure is Delete locked, or if any element is the target of a link sourced on an element with the RolePlayer lock AND that element is outside the closure.
member.param: This partition
Roots of the object graphs to delete
A list of domain role ID-s through which delete should not be propagated.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition.SortByDependency(System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection{Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ModelElement})
member.summary: This function sorts ModelElements in the parameter such that, ElementLinks are placed before their corresponding linkEnds. It also handles edge cases where the linkEnd itself could be an ElementLink.
member.param: Element Collection of ModelElements and ElementLinks to be sorted
member.returns: sorted list
member.example: Consider the elementList { MelA, Link1, MelB } where Link1 is between MelA and MelB. MelA has Link1 as dependent. MelB has Link1 as dependent. This is because if either MelA or MelB is deleted, Link1 has to be deleted, making Link1 a dependent of MelA and MelB. Link1 has no dependants since, deleting Link1 does not imply that MelA or MelB will be deleted. So this function will return a list back that is either {Link1, MelA, MelB} or {Link1, MelB, MelA}.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.Partition.SortLinkOfLinksByDependency(System.Collections.Generic.List{Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.ElementLink})
member.summary: Sort given collection of links topologically, such that if LinkA has LinkB as end, LinkA will appear before LinkB in the result.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SafeWindowTarget
member.summary:
Exception hardening work. This class can be used to filter messages sent to a control, and catch/display all non-critical exceptions. Otherwise, Watson will be invoked and will take down the process, potentially resulting in data loss. See document referenced in bug 427820 for more details. Use this class to wrap an existing IWindowTarget as follows (c is a Control):
c.WindowTarget = new SafeWindowTarget(c.WindowTarget);

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SafeWindowTarget.System#Windows#Forms#IWindowTarget#OnMessage(System.Windows.Forms.Message@)
member.devdoc: The main wndproc for the control. Wrapped to display non-critical exceptions to the user.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SafeWindowTarget.ReplaceWindowTargetRecursive(System.IServiceProvider,System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Replaces the WindowTarget for all child controls of the specified collection. In Debug builds, this will assert that any child controls added after this call must have their WindowTarget replaced as well.
member.param: The ServiceProvider.
The collection of controls to recurse through and replace their target.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.SafeWindowTarget.ReplaceWindowTargetRecursive(System.IServiceProvider,System.Collections.ICollection,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Replaces the WindowTarget for all child controls of the specified collection.
member.param: The ServiceProvider.
The collection of controls to recurse through and replace their target.
If true, in Debug builds, this will assert that any controls added after this call must have their WindowTarget replaced as well.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoState
member.summary: UndoState enumeration describes state of Undo in the Undo Manager

member.summary: Undo is enabled

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoState.Disabled
member.summary: Undo is enabled

member.name: F:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoState.DisabledNoFlush
member.summary: UNDONE: mattcur: Use this value at your own peril. Disabling the undo stack without flushing it is extremely dangerous and can leave the internal model inconsistent. However, there is no real alternative for keeping files from dirtying in response to changes that affect the UI and internal state but not the document files. DisabledNoFlush will be marked as obsolete as soon as possible.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoManager
member.summary: Summary description for UndoManager.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoManager.UndoStackFlushed
member.summary: Allows clients to receive an event when the undo stack is flushed

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoManager.RedoStackFlushed
member.summary: Allows clients to receive an event when the redo stack is flushed
member.remarks: The RedoStackFlushed event w/IsUndoStackAltered set true, will always follow the UndoStackFlushed event. Listening for the RedoStackFlushed event is useful in the case that it's IsUndoStackAltered argument is set false. This indicates that the redo stack is being flushed seperately from the entire undo stack.

member.name: E:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Modeling.UndoManager.UndoItemAdded
member.summary: Event that is fired every time an undo item is added to the undo stack
